hints_html:
To begin with, what are the dimensions of the matrix C that we are looking for?

Multiply B with a general matrix

\[\begin{aligned} C = \begin{bmatrix} a & d \\ b & e \\ c & f \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

and then solve the resulting four equations.

Another solution attempt can be given by only looking at the first two columns of B and find the matrix inverse of this 2x2 matrix. Then, add a row of zeros to that inverse matrix you found.
hints_latex:
To begin with, what are the dimensions of the matrix \emph{C} that we
are looking for?

Another solution attempt can be given by only looking at the first two
columns of \emph{B} and find the matrix inverse of this 2x2 matrix.
Then, add a row of zeros to that inverse matrix you found.
hints_raw:
To begin with, what are the dimensions of the matrix ''C'' that we are looking for?
Multiply ''B'' with a general matrix
:<math>
C = \begin{bmatrix}
a & d \\ b & e \\ c & f
\end{bmatrix}
</math>

and then solve the resulting four equations.
Another solution attempt can be given by only looking at the first two columns of ''B'' and find the matrix inverse of this 2x2 matrix. Then, add a row of zeros to that inverse matrix you found.
question: A 11
sols_html:
Let \(C = \begin{bmatrix} a & d \\ b & e \\ c & f \end{bmatrix}\). Then multiplying out the required matrix gives

\[\begin{aligned} \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix} = BC &= \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 & -1 \\ -3 & 1 & 0 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} a & d \\ b & e \\ c & f \end{bmatrix}\\ &= \begin{bmatrix} (1)(a)+(0)(b) + (-1)(c) & (1)(d) + (0)(e) + (-1)(f) \\ (-3)(a) + (1)(b) + (0)(c) & (-3)(d) + (1)(e) + (0)(f) \end{bmatrix}\\ &= \begin{bmatrix} a-c & d-f \\ -3a + b & -3d + e \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

This gives the equations

\[\begin{aligned} a-c &= 1\\ d-f &= 0 \\ -3a + b &= 0 \\ -3d + e &= 1\end{aligned}\]

Setting simple values like \(a=1\) and \(e=1\) gives us that \(b=3,c=0,d=0,f=0\). This is a valid solution and thus such a matrix C exists and is given by

\(C = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 3 & 1 \\ 0 & 0 \end{bmatrix}\)

Proceeding as in hint 3, we find the inverse of

\(\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ -3 & 1 \end{bmatrix}\)

which is given by

\(\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 3 & 1 \end{bmatrix}\)

Thus, a matrix C that will work is

\(\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 3 & 1 \\ 0 & 0 \end{bmatrix}\)

Since the zeroes at the bottom will cancel any terms in the last column of B once you perform the matrix multiplication \(BC\).
sols_latex:
Proceeding as in hint 3, we find the inverse of

$\begin{bmatrix}
1 & 0 \\ -3 & 1
\end{bmatrix}$

which is given by

$\begin{bmatrix}
1 & 0 \\ 3 & 1
\end{bmatrix}$

Thus, a matrix C that will work is

$\begin{bmatrix}
1 & 0 \\ 3 & 1 \\ 0 & 0 
\end{bmatrix}$

Since the zeroes at the bottom will cancel any terms in the last column
of B once you perform the matrix multiplication $BC$.
statement_html:
Let

\[\begin{aligned} A = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 3 \\ 3 & 8 \end{bmatrix} \qquad B = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 & -1 \\ -3 & 1 & 0 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

Calculate the following whenever defined. Otherwise state undefined and include a brief explanation.

A matrix \(C\) such that \(BC = I_{2}\) where \(I_{2}\) is the \(2\times 2\) identity matrix.
